sect2.title: Minimum System Requirements for the x86_64 Platform

listitem.para: any AMD64/Intel* EM64T processor (32-bit processors are not supported)

3.5 GB available disk space (more recommended)

sect2.title: Installing &productname;
sect2.para: Starting with &productname; 15, the installation medium only consists of the &leanos;, a minimal, command line-based system for installing, updating and registering &productname;. During the installation you can add functionality by selecting modules, that will be installed on top of the &leanos;.

A default installation requires network access to either contact the &scc; or a local &smtool; server to retrieve repository data for the modules. In case you want to perform an installation without network access, a second installation medium, the package DVD 2017-10-04 - fs: Terminology?, is required. 2017-10-04 - fs: Where to get the package DVD ISO? Name?

step.para: Boot from the &leanos; media. On machines equipped with UEFI you will see the graphical boot screen shown below. Secure boot on UEFI machines is supported. On machines equipped with a traditional BIOS, a slightly different boot screen is used.
Select Installation at the boot screen, then press . This boots the system and loads the &productname; installer.

tip.title: Changing the Language and Setting Boot Parameters
tip.para: By default, the installation will be started with American English and the boot media as the installation source. A DHCP lookup will be performed to configure the network. These defaults can be changed.

On machine equipped with a traditional BIOS, use F2 to change the language for the installer. A corresponding keyboard layout is chosen automatically. Use other function keys as indicated on the boot screen to select more boot options or manually specify them at the boot prompt.
On UEFI machines, select Installation on the boot screen and then press E to access the editor for the boot entry. Navigate to the end of the following line:
To change the language and keyboard layout, add a the following paramater preceded by a :
Supported values for LANGUAGE are, among others, cs_CZ, de_DE, es_ES, fr_FR, ja_JP, pt_BR, pt_PT, ru_RU, zh_CN, and zh_TW.
If needed, add more parameters the same way. Parameters need to be separated by a space. To boot the edited entry, press F10. If you access the machine via serial console, press 0

step.para: The Language and Keyboard Layout are initialized with the language settings you have chosen on the boot screen. Change them here, if necessary. Use the Keyboard Test text box to test the layout.
With the &leanos; you can install all &sle; base products:

listitem.para: &sls;
&sles4sap;
&sled;
&slehpc;

step.para: Select a product for installation. You need to have a regsitration code for the respective product. In the course of this document it is assumed you have chosen &sls;&sled;. Proceed with Next.

tip.title: Release Notes
tip.para: From this point on, the Release Notes can be viewed from any screen during the installation process by selecting Release Notes.

step.para: Read the License Agreement. It is presented in the language you have chosen on the boot screen. Translations are available via the License Language drop-down box . You need to accept the agreement by checking I Agree to the License Terms to install &productname;. Proceed with Next.

A system analysis is performed, where the installer probes for storage devices, and tries to find other installed systems. If the network was automatically configured via DHCP during the start of the installation, you will be taken to the registration step.

If the network is not yet configured, the Network Settings dialog opens. Choose a network interface from the list and configure it with Edit. Alternatively, Add an interface manually. See and for more information. If you prefer to do an installation without network access, skip this step without making any changes and proceeding with Next.

To get technical support and product updates, you need to register and activate your product with the &scc; or a local registration server. Registering &productname; at this stage also grants you immediate access to the update repository. This enables you to install the system with the latest updates and patches available.

When registering, repositories and dependencies for the modules, which you will install with the next step, are loaded from the registration server. This ensures that you do not need a second installation media.

To register with the &scc;, enter the e-mail address associated with your SCC account and the registration code for &productname;. If your organization provides a local registration server, you may alternatively register there. Activate Register System via local SMT Server and either choose a URL from the drop-down box or type in an address.

tip.title: Installing Product Patches at Installation Time
tip.para: After &productname; has been successfully registered, you are asked whether to install the latest available online updates during the installation. If choosing Yes, the system will be installed with the most current packages without having to apply the updates after installation. Activating this option is recommended.

step.para: If you are offline or want to skip this step, activate Skip Registration. You can register your system at any time later from the installed system. Note that you will need the package DVD 2017-10-06 - fs: Terminology? to proceed with the installation of the modules.

step.remark: 2017-10-06 - fs: Offline installation is still missing
step.para: After the system is successfully registered, the installer lists modules and extensions that are available for &productname;. Modules are components which allow you to shape the product according to your needs. They are free of charge. Extension extend the capabilities of your product. They are offered as subscriptions and require a registration key that is liable for costs.

The availability of certain modules or extensions depends on the product you have chosen in the first step of this installation. For a detailed description of the modules and their life cycles, click a module. The following modules and extensions are available for &productname;:
step.remark: 2017-10-06 - fs: I would like to link to an official statement regarding the lifecycle of modules here...

listitem.para: This module adds a basic system on top of &leanos;. It is required by all other modules and extensions. The scope of an installation, only containing the base system, is comparable to the installation patter minimal system of previous &productname; versions.
Adds a graphical user interface (Wayland) and essential desktop applications to the system. This module also is a prerequisite for the server applications and the development tools module.
Contains compiler (including gcc) and libraries required for compiling and debugging applications.

Contains packages, that were available in previous versions of &productname;, but have been discontinued in &slsa; &productnumber;. This module is recommended when migration from a previous &slsa; version.

Contains all tools required to create images for deploying &productnumber; in cloud environments such as the Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, Google Compute Platform, or the &suse; OpenStack Cloud.

Contains packages for PHP, Ruby on Rails, and Python that are not provided by other modules. If you use one of these languages, install this module. It is also required to install the desktop applications and public cloud modules.
Adds server functionality by providing network services such as DHCP server, name server, or Web server.
Adds clustering support for mission critical setups to &productname;.

Extends the functionality of &productname; with packages from &sled;, like additional desktop applications (office suite, email client, graphical editor ...) and libraries. It allows to combine both products to create a fully featured wWorkstation.

step.para: As stated above, some modules depend on the installation of other modules. Therefore, you can only select a module for installation, when it's dependencies are fulfilled.
Select the modules and extension you would like to install and proceed with Next. In case you have chosen one or more extension, you will be prompted to provide the respective registration codes.

The Add-on Product dialog allows you to add additional software sources (so-called repositories) to &productname;, that are not provided by the &scc;. Such add-on products may include third-party products and drivers or additional software for your system.

tip.title: Adding Drivers During the Installation
tip.para: You can also add driver update repositories via the Add-On Product dialog. Driver updates for &sle; are provided at . These drivers have been created via the &suse; SolidDriver Program.

step.para: If you want to skip this step, proceed with Next. Otherwise activate I would like to Install an Add-on Product. Specify a media type, a local path, or a network resource hosting the repository and follow the on-screen instructions.

Check Download Repository Description Files to download the files describing the repository now. If deactivated, they will be downloaded after the installation has started. Proceed with Next and insert a medium if required. Depending on the product's content it may be necessary to accept additional license agreements. Proceed with Next. If you have chosen an add-on product requiring a registration key, you will be asked to enter it before proceeding to the next step.

Choose the System Role that meets your requirements best. Select Default System for physical machines or virtual guests. For a virtualization host that can run other virtual machines, select KVM Virtualization Host or Xen Virtualization Host.
Review the partition setup proposed by the system. If necessary, change it. You have the following options:

listitem.para: Starts a wizard which lets you refine the partitioning proposal. Options available here depend on your system setup. In case it contains more than a single hard disk, you may choose which disk(s) to use and where to place the root partition. If the disk(s) already contain partitions, decide whether to remove or resize them.
In subsequent steps you may also add LVM support and disk encryption. You can change the file system for the root partition and decide whether to have a separate home partition or not.
Opens the Expert Partitioner described in . This gives you full control over the partitioning setup and lets you create a custom setup. This option is intended for experts.

step.para: To accept the proposed setup without any changes, choose Next to proceed.

Select the clock and time zone to use in your system. To manually adjust the time or to configure an NTP server for time synchronization, choose Other Settings. See for detailed information. Proceed with Next.
To create a local user, type the first and last name in the Userâ€™s Full Name field, the login name in the Username field, and the password in the Password field.

The password should be at least eight characters long and should contain both uppercase and lowercase letters and numbers. The maximum length for passwords is 72 characters, and passwords are case-sensitive.

For security reasons it is also strongly recommended not to enable the Automatic Login. You should also not Use this Password for the System Administrator but rather provide a separate &rootuser; password in the next installation step. Proceed with Next.
Type a password for the system administrator account (called the &rootuser; user).
You should never forget the &rootuser; password! After you entered it here, the password cannot be retrieved. See for more information. Proceed with Next.

Use the Installation Settings screen to review and—if necessary—change several proposed installation settings. The current configuration is listed for each setting. To change it, click the headline. Some settings, such as firewall or SSH can directly be changed by clicking the respective links.

tip.title: Remote Access
tip.para: Changes you can make here, can also be made later at any time from the installed system. However, if you need remote access directly after the installation, you should adjust the Firewall and SSH settings according to your needs.

listitem.para: The scope of the installation is defined by the modules and extensions you have chosen for this installation. However, depending on your selection, not all packages available in a module, are selected for installation.

Clicking Software opens the Software Selection and System Tasks screen, where you can change the software selection by selecting or deselecting patterns. Each pattern contains several software packages needed for specific functions (for example, KVM Host Server). For a more detailed selection based on software packages to install, select Details to switch to the &yast; Software Manager. See for more information.
This section shows the boot loader configuration. Changing the defaults is only recommended if really needed. Refer to for details.

listitem.remark: 2017-10-06 - fs: Check whether this still applies when firewalld is taken into account by the installation routines...
listitem.para: By default, the Firewall is enabled with the active network interface configured for the external zone. See for configuration details.
The SSH service is disabled by default, its port (22) is closed. Therefore logging in from remote is not possible by default. Click enable and open to toggle these settings.

Kdump saves the memory image (core dump) to the file system in case the kernel crashes. This enables you to find the cause of the crash by debugging the dump file. Kdump is preconfigured and enabled by default. See for more information.

In case you have installed the desktop applications module, the system boots into the graphical target, with network, multiuser and display manager support. Switch to multi-user if you do not need to log in via display manager.
View detailed hardware information by clicking System. In the resulting screen you can also change Kernel Settings—see for more information.

step.para: After you have finalized the system configuration on the Installation Settings screen, click Install. Depending on your software selection you may need to agree to license agreements before the installation confirmation screen pops up. Up to this point no changes have been made to your system. After you click Install a second time, the installation process starts.

During the installation, the progress is shown in detail on the Details tab.

After the installation routine has finished, the computer is rebooted into the installed system. Log in and start &yast; to fine-tune the system. If you are not using a graphical desktop or are working from remote, refer to for information on using &yast; from a terminal.
